results.headline: Careful, That Fanciful Being Has Some Serious Backup

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rise of the Guardians

results.summary_short: In the animated film “Rise of the Guardians,” mythical beings like the Tooth Fairy and Santa Claus fight off threats.

results.headline: The Calm Before the Kablooey

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Silver Linings Playbook

results.summary_short: “Silver Linings Playbook,” directed by David O. Russell, finds a man, played by Bradley Cooper, returning home after a stint in a mental institution.

results.headline: When Dad’s a Nazi Monster, How Do You Cope?

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hitler's Children

results.summary_short: “Hitler’s Children,” directed by Chanoch Ze’evi, looks at five children or other relatives of German war criminals trying to figure out how to compensate for evil deeds.

results.headline: For the Stranded Yoga Faithful, the Zen Is Gone With the Electricity

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of First Winter

results.summary_short: In “First Winter” a group of Brooklyn residents react in various ways to being stranded at a country farmhouse during a blackout.

results.headline: Infidelity, Grandly Staged

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Anna Karenina

results.summary_short: The director Joe Wright and the screenwriter Tom Stoppard create a playful, passionate rendering of Leo Tolstoy’s novel “Anna Karenina.”

results.headline: Writing Ads That Sell His Soul

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Generation P

results.summary_short: Set in early post-Soviet Russia, “Generation P” is the story of a disillusioned poet-turned-adman searching for spirituality in the trash can of the marketplace.

results.headline: Boy? Girl? And Other Questions

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Turning

results.summary_short: “Turning,” a film by Charles Atlas and Antony, follows Antony’s band on a tour of Europe.

results.headline: Infusing the Bloodline With a Problem Child
results.display_title: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn - Part Two

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn - Part Two

results.summary_short: A newborn half-human, half-vampire child is the nominal centerpiece for the final movie in the “Twilight” franchise.

results.headline: Being a Guinea Pig for Pay May Not Be Worth It

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Normals

results.summary_short: In “The Normals,” directed by Kevin Connors, a jobless man in his 20s agrees to take an experimental antipsychotic drug to escape debt collectors.

results.headline: Like a Sailboat Skipper Without a Destination

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Comedy

results.summary_short: “The Comedy,” by Rick Alverson, is about a young man with too much time and money on his hands.

results.headline: Meet the New Boss: She’s Not at All Like the Old One

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Price Check

results.summary_short: Parker Posey plays the new, hard-charging boss of a supermarket chain in this workplace comedy.

results.headline: Rounding Up Jews in France

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Round Up

results.summary_short: “La Rafle” is a well-meaning but inexpertly dramatized account of the detention of 13,000 Parisian Jews in 1942.

results.headline: The Course of Love, Written on the Walls

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Habibi

results.summary_short: Susan Youssef’s debut, “Habibi” tells the story of a Palestinian couple in Gaza separated by religious strictures and class.

results.headline: Check-In, Check-Out Affair

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 28 Hotel Rooms

results.summary_short: In “28 Hotel Rooms” an unnamed couple meet in a hotel bar, have a one-night stand and begin a long-running, clandestine affair.

results.headline: Hunt for Truth Behind a Man and Cinema

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Man Vanishes

results.summary_short: “A Man Vanishes” starts out as a documentary about a missing person, but as it goes on actors pose as investigators and soon there are no lines between fiction and reality.

results.headline: Defuse Bombs? That’s Nothing Next to Love

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jab Tak Hai Jaan

results.summary_short: In “Jab Tak Hai Jaan,” the final film by the director Yash Chopra, a bomb defuser finds himself in a love triangle.

results.headline: Profile of a Great Has-Been Granted One Last Chance

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Barrymore

results.summary_short: Christopher Plummer reprises his stage role in “Barrymore,” about a hypothetical John Barrymore comeback.

results.headline: Lawyers and the Seasoning of Justice in Israel’s Occupied Territories

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Law in These Parts

results.summary_short: “The Law in These Parts” is a documentary investigation into the justice of the legal system in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

results.headline: Portrait of the Sad Life of Child Boxers in Thailand

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Buffalo Girls

results.summary_short: “Buffalo Girls” profiles two 8-year-olds working the underground child-boxing circuit in rural Thailand, with their parents’ approval.

results.headline: Less Than Visible, but Not to Each Other

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Starlet

results.summary_short: Two women, decades apart in age but bonded by their relative invisibility, connect in Sean Baker’s “Starlet.”
